text:
BRIAN KENNY: Welcome to
Managing Through Crisis,

the webcast featuring faculty
from Harvard Business School,

sharing insights for
managers on how to navigate
through the COVID-19 crisis.

On February 2nd of
this year, 52 brands

spent an average of $7.7
million to strut their stuff

on the annual advertising
extravaganza known as the Super
Bowl.

Oh, and there was a
football game too.

It's a big day for
those brands as it often

sets the stage for
advertising and promotion
for the rest of the year.

Little did we know on that day
that within weeks, those plans
would be erased by COVID-19.

Chief marketing officers
everywhere find themselves
in uncharted waters.

So today, I'm
really happy to have

two guests who can
help us navigate
through these rough seas.

They recently
co-wrote an article

called What Customers
Need to Hear from You
During the COVID-19 Crisis.

Jill Avery is an expert
on brand management

who teaches in the MBA program
at Harvard Business School.

Richard Edelman is the CEO of
the PR firm, Edelman Worldwide.

And every year, they publish
a report called the Annual
Edelman Trust Barometer.

It's a fantastic
report, and we're
going to talk about that today.

But let me thank both of
you for joining us today.

RICHARD EDELMAN:
Thanks for having us.
JILL AVERY: Thank you, Brian.

BRIAN KENNY: So
we're all separate.

We're practicing
social distancing.

We're here from
places in the country.

Richard, I want
to start with you.

I mentioned the Edelman
Trust Barometer.

It's something that we
refer to at Harvard Business

School every year because I
think the information that you

provide in there gives us a real
way to gauge what people are

thinking about the government,
media, and business
institutions.

But you've just done a
little bit of an off cycle
version of this.

And I want you to
maybe describe for us

what the research
was that you did,

and how it feeds
the topic that we're
going to talk about today.

RICHARD EDELMAN: I think the
big message for marketers

is that your customers
want to hear from you.
Don't do a blackout.

Tell them what you're
doing to solve the problem
and not sell to them.

Have a mentality that
is suitably serious.

Don't be too much
around comic relief.
And be substantive.

Give them something
tangible that you're doing.

Whether it's cutting rates,
or allowing health workers

to jump the line, or having a
idea that that's even bigger,

like the Hawaii
tourism, where they
have this feeling of aloha.

They did a video and said,
hey, we're all thinking of you.
We'll be back together soon.
The Aloha spirit.
But communicate.

Because now's the
time people need
to feel the empathy of brands.

BRIAN KENNY: Richard,
who did you--
I'm just curious.

Like what were the numbers of
the folks that you surveyed?

And how did you go
about executing?

RICHARD EDELMAN: So we went
out to a dozen markets.
We did 12,000 people.

Some in Asia, some in
Europe, some in the states,
some in Latin America.

And the amazing thing
was the unanimity

of feeling of the
respondents, young and old,
and across all the geographies.

They really actually
believe deeply in brands.

They have this sense that
brands are money for them

today, the idea
of brand democracy

that I'm voting by
buying your product.

And I'll support you, candidate
brand, if in fact, you

do what I expect, which
is stand up for me
at this really tough time.

BRIAN KENNY: Jill,
before coming to HBS,

you were at the fore of
some pretty big brand,

probably some Super
Bowl advertisers
I would venture to guess.

And I'm wondering like, how big
of an impact is this on a CMO

when something like--
we don't really
have a precedent for say.
I don't know.
Maybe 9/11.
Some people have said that.

But how does the CMO
pivot in a time like this?
JILL AVERY: Yeah.

This is a very scary time
for chief marketing officers,
Brian.

And what precipitated
our study is

that we notice that
nearly a quarter of brands

had gone dark as a result
of the COVID-19 crisis.

So CMOs were struggling
with what do I do?
What do I say?

How do I act during
a crisis like this?

I'm not sure we have a
precedent in history for this.

And I think that's why you
saw so many managers choosing

to go dark, rather than
experimenting with solutions
to address the crisis.

So we feel that this survey,
the week of March 23rd, which

if you go back in your
memory, was as the crisis was
unfolding across the world.

So some of the markets
that we surveyed,

consumers were well
into weeks of having
the virus in their country.

Whereas in other parts of
the world where we surveyed,

the virus was just
emerging or threatening
to come into a country.

So managers all
over the world were

at different places
during that week

and trying to
understand how consumers

would respond to this very
unique, unprecedented event.

BRIAN KENNY: What
kind of an impact

do you think this has on
the advertising industry?

Richard, that might be a
question that you're closer to.

How is it impacting
the media world?

RICHARD EDELMAN:
Well, what's happened

is that all sorts of
brands have decided

to stop putting their content
next to disturbing news.
And that's not unusual.

But if most of the
news is disturbing,

that means basically,
they're opting out.

And so actually, advertising in
television in the third quarter
could be down as much as 40%.

And so it's having a tidal
wave on the advertising
and marketing business.

Specifically, WPP applied
for $600 million sterling
of government support yesterday.

And the stock price of
WPP is down by half.

And the request for
layoffs, or furloughs,

or senior salary cuts is
just sweeping the industry.

So it's definitely
having an effect.

But what I would say is it's
urgent that it's remembered.

Everybody knows where
you were on 2001, 9/11.
And the same will be for brands.

If you stand up and speak up
for your brands right now,

you will have a
disproportionate impact

because the others
are being silent.

And if it's
functional, like Dove,

to wash your hands more
often and for 20 seconds,
that's the new rule.

You have to do
tops, and bottoms,
and between the fingers.

Or if it's for HP
donating digital printers

to hospitals, where they
don't have enough masks,
and they can make their own.

That's the sort of
responsibility people
will remember.

BRIAN KENNY: So Jill,
let me ask you about this

because you and I have talked
before about brand storytelling
and how important that is.

And I'm wondering, there
are some brands who
are lighthearted and frivolous.

And that's kind of like
their brand personality.

If you're a brand
like that, what

can you do to adapt to this
and still be authentic and true
to yourself?

JILL AVERY: So I think
two messages here.

One is you have to be
present during this moment.

So even though so many
CMOs are pulling back,

this is not the
moment to go dark.

And whether it's in digital
media or traditional media,

you're seeing consumers
hunger for information
about this crisis.

So consumers are consuming more
media during this time period.

And they want to hear
directly from their brands.

So when we think about brand
storytelling during this time,
consumers want information.
They want facts about the virus.

They want to understand how
your products and services can
help them weather this crisis.

And they want to make sure
that you're delivering
news that is factual.

There's a lot of rumor and
fake news going around.

And consumers are
really looking to brands

to be truthful, upfront,
and well-informed,
and educated about the crisis.

Our survey results
indicate that marketers

might want to be cautious
about the use of humor

or being too lighthearted
during the crisis.

Consumers indicated
that they want

all advertisers to recognize
that we're in a crisis.

To empathize with
consumers' conditions.

To show that they understand
what people are going through.

That they're not
ignoring or oblivious
to the state of the world.

So we would caution
marketers right now

to avoid being frivolous,
to watch the use of humor.

The other theme that
came up is escapism.

Should we be creating
brand stories

that allow consumers to
escape this period, which

is very, very scary
both from a health

standpoint, a social distancing
standpoint, and economic pain.

Our survey results indicate that
that might be a risky strategy

right now, especially
for countries that
are in the heart of the crisis.

Perhaps as more weeks go
on, escapism in advertising
might be more palatable.

But in the heart of the
crisis, consumers really

want to see how you're
helping and how you're

providing solutions that
are going to help them
through this moment.

RICHARD EDELMAN: There's
one thing that is amazing.

How fast a lie gets around
the world in a time of panic.

And so there was some report
from an unidentified UN

official in Malaysia
saying that if you

had cold products
like ice cream,

it opened your
throat up for COVID.

And all of a sudden, ice
cream started to plummet.

And we, on behalf of Unilever,
said that is just not so.

We had to put doctors up
quite quickly, go on social,
and say enjoy your ice cream.

It's actually not only
fun, it's totally safe.

But this idea of being
ready for fake news

is so important right now
because it's just getting
up and around so quickly.

BRIAN KENNY: Richard, is
this a time that you would
advise CEOs to step forward?

I mean, do we want to
hear from CEOs now?

Is it important to have
their voice register?

RICHARD EDELMAN: So Brian,
we're about to put out

another Special Element
Report next Tuesday.
And here's what I'd say.

At the moment, CEOs have
kept their heads down.

They've sort of been
the passenger in the car

and letting government
be the driver.

And when return to work happens,
they can't do that anymore.

And business is going to have
to be the responsible and staged

return to work in
such a way that people
feel it's different.

Starbucks, for example, opening
its stores by having no one

sit, just getting served, and
leaving, and staging the line
such that no one's too close.

And all of these things are
signals that businesses thought

through, that the thing
that matters the most

is safety of their people
and of their customers.
Not the money.
And that's urgent.

And so CEOs to the point
should be speaking up now.

They've had their
three months of quiet.

Now they need to
stand up and speak up

on behalf of what's the new
society that we can expect?
And don't pine for the old.

Tell us what the new
normal is going to be.

BRIAN KENNY: Jill, are
there examples of firms--

I know naming names is
always dicey in our business.

But there examples
that you can point

to where somebody has
really adopted a tone that

captures what you're
describing as the right tone
for this time?
JILL AVERY: Sure.

I think I'll point to
some of the efforts

that we've seen
coming out of Unilever

because they have been
one of the companies

that I think have taken a total
360 view of how to communicate
during this crisis.

First, there is a very
powerful ad out there right

now that is entitled,
courage is beautiful.

And it features
frontline health workers

with their tired, haggard,
and hard-working faces

marked and scarred by the masks
that they're wearing as they're
caring for COVID-19 patients.

It's part of the Dove campaign
for real beauty, which

has been a long running,
very successful campaign
for Unilever.

And it perfectly
matches the essence

of the brand and the
message that everyone

is beautiful with a
new version of beauty

and a new version of
courage and heroism
during the COVID-19 crisis.

I think it strikes a perfect
emotional balance and message
for the times.

But Unilever is not
just advertising.

They're not just
telling nice stories
during this time period.

They're actually putting
action behind the words.

And so I think what makes
Dove and their other brands

campaigns more powerful right
now is the fact that Unilever

has dedicated 100
million euros in soaps,

and bleach, and
other food products
to help with the crisis.

They've pledged
200 million euros

to help their small
suppliers and small retailers
weather the crisis.

And they promised to
protect their employees

for three months as the
economic situation changes.

So here, you see a firm
that's helping its employees,

helping its suppliers,
providing emotional connections

for viewers, and then
also adding to it

with videos on proper
hand-washing techniques
using Dove soap on YouTube.

So kind of a 360 view of being
informational, providing help

to not just their own customers,
but to people around the world,

and really standing
behind their brand values.

BRIAN KENNY: That's
a great example.

And Richard, I guess I would
ask you then, sort of as a
follow on to that.

The consumers want
their brands to be
part of the solution here.

How important is it to
consumers that brands actually

step up and try to do
something proactive to be
part of the solution?

RICHARD EDELMAN: It's
the cynical unknown.

They are absolutely convinced
that brands are the leading
edge of the spear in solving.

In fact, they actually
want brands to protect
the jobs of employees.

They want brands to lower prices
for people who are affected
adversely by all of this.

They have just this
sense that the brand

is the corporation in
a way because that's
what they can buy.
They can't buy the corporation.

And the brand also
shouldn't be selling.

The brand should be solving
and be part of a fabric.

In fact, maybe partnering
with government

or partnering with NGOs
because we're better together.

Unilever, for example, is doing
a day of service in the United

States where they're giving
away all the products made

in their 14 factories
on one day in May.

They're distributing
through Feeding America
and direct relief.

And that's smart
because it gives them

the ability to also
reach their employees
and their communities.
It's not just the customers.

BRIAN KENNY: So
I'll stay with you

for a second on this,
Richard, because I

think there are some brands,
particularly in the meatpacking

industry right now,
where we've seen
high incidences of the virus.

Those plants, many of
them are under shut down.

And so you've got a brand
like Tyson let's say, who

finds itself in a
really difficult spot

because either they care
about their employees,

and they stay shut down until
they can do the deep cleaning

they need to do, or they
care about the public,

and they stay open, so that
they can avoid some disruption
to the food chain.

What kind of a trade off do you
have to make there as a brand?

RICHARD EDELMAN:
Well, it's our client,
so I know something about this.
And in fact I don't think--

BRIAN KENNY: I didn't know
that, by the way, when
I asked the questions.

RICHARD EDELMAN: They actually
don't need to make a tradeoff.

What they need to
be able to do is

demonstrate that
they've actually
changed the production method.

They have put plastics between
each of the workstations.

They have monitored
the employees
coming in with temperature.

They have made efforts to
help the community, not just

their own workers, get
to a better health place.

And it is urgent
on food suppliers

to have people be able
to do this vital work.

And so Tyson has all of a sudden
become a health care company.

And I think that's the thing
that's changed for industry.
You're not just a meat company.

You have to care more broadly
about your environment,
so that you can do your job.

BRIAN KENNY: So
Jill, I know Richard

said that this is
a time for brands
to be solving and not selling.

But I have to ask, is there
an opportunity for brands

here to grow, mindshare,
and eventually

to grow their consumer
base based on how
they behave during this time?

JILL AVERY: I think
there's a huge opportunity,

but I also think
there's a huge risk.

And what we're
hearing from consumers

is they will reward
companies who act honorably
to help during this crisis.

They expect their brands that
they've trusted for many years

to step up and be a safety
net during this time period,

to help governments, to help
non-profit organizations get us
through this.

They're expecting
brands and the companies

behind them to help,
even when they incur
significant financial losses.

So relationships are formed
and strengthened or destroyed
in moments of crisis.

So I think consumers
are watching right now

and will reward brands
who do this well.

They also, unfortunately,
are indicating that they
will punish brands who fail.

Who sell rather than
provide solutions.

Who take advantage
of the situation,

rather than being
compassionate in this moment.

They will punish
brands who don't

take care of their
employees or who

leave people behind during
this moment of crisis.

So I think if we're
managing brands,

it's a tremendous opportunity
to increase trust,

to secure loyalty, and to be
there alongside our customers.

But it's also a risk for
those who strike the wrong

or don't step up to
be a helping partner.

BRIAN KENNY: So I've got
one more question left.

I want you to both have an
opportunity to respond to it.
Richard, I'll start with you.

The question is how
should CMOs almost
be thinking about the restart?

This will come to an
end at some point.

And how does CMOs need
to think about their role

in bringing their brands
back to the surface?

RICHARD EDELMAN: So I
would hope that CMOs

don't look at this as the
closing of one chapter
and the beginning of another.

Because there is some risk
that COVID could come back.

Business could be blamed for
not being sufficiently cautious
and protecting us.

And so I think it's in a way
the beginning of the next phase
for marketing.

I think people are tired
of being talked at.

I think they want to
be communicated with.

I think there's a sense
that this is beyond purpose.
This is not a nice to do.

This is how our brand is
going to fit into society that

needs to be recreated
and be somehow
in a way good for everybody?

One of the great
changes here, Brian,

is we have 30 million people
unemployed in the United
States.

This wave of COVID has caused
an economic catastrophe.

And 50% of Hispanics
at the moment

are either unemployed or
have had their wages or hours
diminished.

And so we have to really
think as marketers,

how are we going to
have products that suit
the people who are out of work?
They're not poor.
They're disadvantaged now.
And we need to give them hope.

And we need to give
them a sense of we care

and that we're designing
smaller products
or affordable products.

It's a rethink
not just of safety

and where you sit
in the restaurant,

but how I priced this,
and how I market this,

and how I'm going to let
people talk to each other?

And in a way, maybe be less
controlling on our message.

That in fact, the brand is
willing to be a community
and really stand for the best.
BRIAN KENNY: Jill?

JILL AVERY: So I
would caution brands

about returning to their
pre-COVID messaging

and their pre-COVID strategy
because I think the best brand

storytelling always
springs when we stay
close to the human condition.

Culture has
fundamentally changed.

And people have
different needs today

than they did back
in February of 2020.

And smart marketers will
tap into the new needs

and the emerging
needs of consumers
as society begins to open up.

Health, safety are
going to be big themes

well into the fall, winter,
and possibly into 2021.

And so how brands can
adapt their storytelling

to reflect the new
needs of consumers,

to respect the
position that consumers

are in both economically,
psychologically, and socially,

and reflect that
in their stories is

going to lead to a reopening
in a new normal that

needs new stories from
brands, not the stories

we've been telling
in the pre-COVID era.

BRIAN KENNY: Jill
Avery, Richard Edelman,

thank you so much
for these insights.

It's been great
talking with you today.
RICHARD EDELMAN: Thank you.
JILL AVERY: Thanks.
